About Work

Impact ✕ Effort Worksheet

Visualize impact and effort for better prioritization

Sequencing projects for a cross-disciplined team of 12 is a constant challenge. As the lead of a team that builds internal analytic tools for 600 MAUs, our projects often have multiple dependencies either among ourselves or with another team. Here is a typical life cycle of a product:

The problems we face during prioritization:

  • What is the logical sequence to execute this product?
  • How can we prioritize projects that are the most impactful to our users?
  • We have limit backend engineers available. Is there any task that requires no backend work we can do to keep the project going forward?
  • What are the quick-win tasks we can bang out, so our users feel the continuous improvement of the product and our team feels the ongoing impact of their works?

This makes me wonder...

What is the best way to evaluate a bunch of ideas simultaneously?

Like in trading card game, what if each project is given a score for its core values? This would help us to compare their strength and weakness stats against each other, rank their importance, and determine which one to pursue or descope.

Introducing the Impact ðŸ˜€ ✕ ðŸ’» Effort worksheet

To make prioritization transparent and easy, I create a simple method to evaluate a bunch of ideas by visualizing its user impact and team effort with a scoring system. Here is how it works:

1 List the projects

List all the ideas along with a brief description.

2 Determine the impact ðŸ˜€
  • Identify who are the users and label them as the column header. Assign the impact score by asking "How useful is the feature to the users from a scale 1 - 3:
  • ðŸ˜€ 1 = nice-to-have
  • ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ 2 = something that will save the userâ€™s time
  • ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ 3 = users have no way to do now. This change will change their life!
  • * This could be assigned by anyone who has intimate knowledge of the users and product.
3 Determine the effort ðŸ’»
  • Identify what type of effort needed to complete the feature, e.g. product, engineering, design, data-science, or product support. Assign the effort score by estimating how many weeks it will take.
  • ðŸ’» 1 = a week

The total scores generally informs the size and influence of the project. For example:

  • ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ ðŸ’» High impact, low effort This is a quick-win task. We should definitely do.
  • ðŸ˜€ ðŸ’» ðŸ’» ðŸ’» Low impact, high effort This is a monolithic task with little upsides. Probably wonâ€™t do right away or resort to a non-build solution.
  • ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ ðŸ˜€ ðŸ’» ðŸ’» ðŸ’» High impact, High effort This is an investment that may worth the bet.

Outcomes

There are many prioritization methodologies on product management out there, but the simplicity of the Impact x Effort worksheet meets our need for a few reasons:

  • Our team builds internal tools. Our users are also our co-workers, which means we have visibility of their goal and feedback about our product, which helps us to determine user priority.
  • Transparency is the biggest win for us. The spreadsheet makes it crystal clear why we should work on a project or not. For our management, the spreadsheet also highlights our staffing gaps by seeing the list of projects the team could have worked on if we have the more people.
  • The Impact x Effort idea has inspired other teams across the BuzzFeed tech to approach prioritization similarly and adapted the ideas for their needs. Here are examples of the prioritization spreadsheet from other teams:

↧ Free free to download the spreadsheet for your use. Email me if you have any idea for improvement. I am always looking for feedbacks. ðŸ™‚
